question.name: 19.2.3.1 Exact equations
question.questiontext:
Exact equations

Consider the differential equation \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=3x^2.\] By direct integration we find that the general solution of this equation is \[y=x^3+C, \] where \(C\) is, as usual, an arbitrary constant of integration.

Next, consider the differential equation \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(yx)=3x^2.\] Again, by direct integration we find that the general solution is \[yx=x^3+C.\]

We now divide this equation by \(x\) to obtain \[y=x^2+\dfrac{C}{x}. \] The differential equation \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(yx)=3x^2\] is called an exact equation. It can effectively be solved by integrating both sides.

If we consider examples of this kind in a more general setting we obtain the following Key Point:

Key Point

The solution of the equation \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(f(x)\cdot y)=g(x) \] is \[f(x)\cdot y=\int g(x)\, \mathrm{d}x \quad \text{or}\quad y=\dfrac{1}{f(x)}\int g(x) \, \mathrm{d}x. \]
